p227_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p227_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p227_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p227_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p227_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p227_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p227_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p227_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p227_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p227_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p227_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p227_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection in the sun's rays by the rain.
p227_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p227_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p227_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p227_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p227_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p227_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p228_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p228_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p228_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p228_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p228_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p228_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p228_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p228_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p228_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p228_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p228_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p228_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p228_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p228_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p228_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p228_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p228_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p228_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p229_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p229_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p229_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p229_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p229_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p229_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p229_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p229_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p229_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p229_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p229_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p229_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p229_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p229_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p229_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p229_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p229_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p229_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p229_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p231_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p231_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p231_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p231_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p231_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p231_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p231_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p231_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p231_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p231_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p231_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from the earth to their home in the sky.
p231_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p231_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p231_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p231_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p231_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p231_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p231_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p232_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p232_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p232_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p232_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p232_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p232_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p232_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p232_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p232_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p232_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p232_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p232_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p232_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p232_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p232_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p232_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p232_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p232_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p232_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p233_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p233_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p233_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p233_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p233_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p233_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p233_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p233_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p233_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p233_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p233_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p233_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p233_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p233_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p233_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p233_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p233_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p233_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p234_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p234_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p234_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p234_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p234_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p234_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p234_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p234_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p234_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p234_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p234_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p234_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p234_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p234_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p234_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p234_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p234_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p234_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p236_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p236_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p236_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p236_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p236_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p236_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p236_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p236_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p236_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p236_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p236_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p236_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p236_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p236_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p236_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p236_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p236_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p237_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p237_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p237_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p237_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p237_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p237_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p237_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p237_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p237_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p237_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p237_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from the earth to their home in the sky.
p237_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p237_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by the reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p237_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p237_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p237_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p237_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p237_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p238_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p238_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p238_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p238_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p238_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p238_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p238_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p238_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p238_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p238_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p238_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p238_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p238_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p238_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p238_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p238_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p238_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p238_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p238_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p239_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p239_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p239_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p239_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p239_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p239_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p239_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p239_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p239_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p239_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p239_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p239_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p239_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p239_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p239_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p239_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p239_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p239_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p239_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p240_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p240_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p240_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p240_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p240_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p240_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p240_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p240_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p240_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p240_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p240_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p240_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p240_018.txt|Aristotle thought the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p240_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p240_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p240_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p240_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p240_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p240_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p244_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p244_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p244_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p244_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p244_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p244_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p244_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p244_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p244_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p244_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p244_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p244_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p244_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p244_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p244_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p244_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p244_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p244_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p245_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p245_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p245_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p245_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p245_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p245_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p245_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p245_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p245_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p245_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p245_016.txt|Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p245_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p245_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p245_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p245_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p245_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p245_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p245_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p245_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p246_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p246_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p246_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p246_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p246_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p246_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p246_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p246_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p246_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p246_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p246_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p246_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p246_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p246_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p246_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p246_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p246_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p246_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p246_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p248_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p248_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p248_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p248_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p248_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p248_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p248_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p248_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p248_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p248_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p248_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p248_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p248_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p248_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p248_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p248_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p248_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p248_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p248_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p249_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.

p249_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.

p250_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p250_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p250_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p250_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p251_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p251_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p251_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p251_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p251_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p251_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p251_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p251_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p251_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p251_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p251_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p251_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p251_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p251_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p251_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p251_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p251_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p251_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p251_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p254_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p254_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p254_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p254_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p254_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p254_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p254_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p254_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p254_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p254_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p254_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p254_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p254_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p254_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p254_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p254_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p254_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p254_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p254_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p255_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p255_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p255_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p255_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p255_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p255_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p255_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p255_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p255_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p255_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p255_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p255_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p255_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p255_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p255_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p255_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p255_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p255_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p255_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p256_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p256_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p256_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p256_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p256_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p256_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p256_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p256_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p256_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p256_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p256_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p256_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p256_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p256_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p256_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p256_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p256_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p256_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p256_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p257_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p257_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p257_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p257_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p257_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p257_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p257_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p257_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p257_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p257_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p257_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p257_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p257_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p257_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p257_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p257_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p258_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p258_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p258_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p258_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p258_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p258_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p258_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p258_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p258_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p258_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p258_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p258_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p258_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p258_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.

p258_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.

p258_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.

p260_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p260_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p260_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p260_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p260_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p260_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p260_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p260_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p260_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p260_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p260_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p260_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p260_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p260_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p260_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p260_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p260_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p260_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p260_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p261_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p261_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p261_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p261_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p261_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p261_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p261_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p261_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p261_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p261_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p261_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p261_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p261_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p261_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p261_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p261_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p261_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p261_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p261_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p262_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p262_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p262_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p262_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p262_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p262_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p262_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p262_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p262_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p262_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p262_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p262_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p262_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p262_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p262_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p262_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p262_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p262_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p262_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p263_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p263_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p263_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p263_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p263_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p263_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p263_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p263_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p263_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p263_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p263_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p263_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p263_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p263_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p263_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p263_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p263_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p263_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p263_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p265_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p265_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p265_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p265_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p265_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p265_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p265_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p265_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p265_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p265_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p265_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p265_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p265_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p265_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p265_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p265_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p265_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p265_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p266_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p266_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p266_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p266_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p266_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p266_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p266_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p266_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p266_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p266_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p266_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p266_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p266_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p266_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p266_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p266_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p266_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p266_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p266_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p267_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p267_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p267_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p267_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p267_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p267_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p267_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p267_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p267_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p267_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p267_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p267_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p267_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p267_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p267_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p267_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p267_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of a super-imposition of a number of bows.
p267_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p267_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p268_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p268_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p268_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p268_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p268_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p268_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p268_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p268_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p268_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p268_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p268_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p268_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p268_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p268_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p268_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p268_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p268_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p269_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p269_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p269_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p269_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p269_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p269_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p269_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p269_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p269_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p269_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p269_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p269_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p269_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p269_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p269_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p269_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drop increases.
p269_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of the number of bows.
p269_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p269_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p270_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p270_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p270_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p270_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p270_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p270_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p270_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p270_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p270_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p270_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p270_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p270_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p270_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p270_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p270_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p270_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p270_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p270_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p270_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.She is given a new deputy minister for transport and planning.

p271_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p271_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p271_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p271_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p271_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p271_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p271_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p271_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p271_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p271_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p271_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p271_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p271_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p271_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p271_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p271_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p271_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p271_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p271_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p272_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p272_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p272_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p272_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p272_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p272_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p272_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p272_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p272_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p272_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p272_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p272_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p272_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p272_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p272_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p272_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p272_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p272_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p272_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p273_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p273_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p273_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, and its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p273_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p273_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p273_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p273_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p273_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p273_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p273_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p273_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p273_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p273_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p273_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p273_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p273_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p273_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p273_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p273_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p275_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p275_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p275_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p275_009.txt|There is , according to the legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p275_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p275_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p275_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbows in various ways.
p275_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p275_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p275_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p275_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p275_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p275_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p275_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p275_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p275_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p275_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p275_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p276_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p276_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p276_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p276_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p276_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p276_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p276_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p276_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p276_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p276_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p276_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p276_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p276_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p276_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p276_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p276_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p276_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p276_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p276_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p277_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p277_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p277_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p277_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p277_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p277_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p277_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p277_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p277_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p277_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p277_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p277_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p277_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p278_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p278_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p278_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p278_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p278_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p278_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p278_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p278_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p278_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p278_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p278_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p278_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p278_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p278_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p278_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p278_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p278_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p278_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p278_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p279_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p279_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p279_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p279_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p279_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p279_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p279_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p279_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p279_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p279_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p279_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p279_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p279_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p279_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p279_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p279_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p279_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p279_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p279_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.
