p280_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p280_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p280_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p280_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p280_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p280_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p280_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p280_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p280_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p280_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p280_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p280_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p280_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p280_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p280_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p280_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p280_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p280_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p280_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p281_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p281_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p281_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p281_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p281_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p281_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p281_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p281_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p281_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p281_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p281_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p281_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p281_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p281_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p281_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p281_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p281_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p281_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p281_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p282_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p282_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p282_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p282_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p282_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p282_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p282_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p282_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p282_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p282_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p282_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p282_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p282_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p282_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p282_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p282_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p282_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p282_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.She is given a new deputy minister for transport and planning.

p283_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p283_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p283_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p283_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p283_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p283_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p283_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p283_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p283_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p283_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p283_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p283_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p283_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p283_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p283_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p283_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p283_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p283_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p283_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p284_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p284_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p284_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p284_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p284_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p284_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p284_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p284_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p284_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p284_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p284_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p284_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p284_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p284_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p284_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p284_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p284_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p284_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p284_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.It's nice to hear.

p285_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p285_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p285_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p285_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p285_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p285_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p285_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p285_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p285_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p285_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p285_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p285_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p285_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p285_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p285_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p285_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p285_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p285_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p285_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p286_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p286_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p286_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p286_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p286_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p286_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p286_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p286_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p286_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p286_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p286_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p286_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p286_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p286_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p286_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p286_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p286_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p286_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p286_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p287_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p287_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p287_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p287_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p287_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p287_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p287_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p287_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p287_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p287_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p287_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p287_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p287_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p287_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p287_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p287_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p287_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p287_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p287_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p288_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p288_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p288_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p288_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p288_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p288_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p288_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p288_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p288_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p288_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p288_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p288_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p288_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p288_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p288_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p288_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p288_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p288_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p288_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p293_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p293_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p293_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p293_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p293_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p293_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he's looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p293_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p293_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p293_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p293_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p293_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p293_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p293_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p293_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p293_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p293_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p293_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p293_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p294_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p294_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p294_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p294_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p294_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p294_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p294_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p294_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p294_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p294_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p294_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p294_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p294_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p294_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it's not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p294_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p294_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p294_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p294_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p294_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p295_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p295_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p295_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p295_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p295_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from the earth to their home in the sky.
p295_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p295_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p295_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.

p297_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p297_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p297_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p297_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p297_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p297_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say that he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p297_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p297_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p297_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p297_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p297_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from the earth to their home in the sky.
p297_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p297_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p297_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not a reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p297_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.

p298_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p298_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p298_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p298_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p298_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p298_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p298_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p298_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p298_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p298_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p298_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p298_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p298_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p298_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p298_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p298_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p298_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p298_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p298_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p299_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p299_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p299_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p299_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p299_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p299_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he's looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p299_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p299_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p299_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p299_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p299_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p299_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p299_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p299_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p299_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p299_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p299_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p299_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p299_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p300_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p300_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p300_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p300_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p300_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p300_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p300_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p300_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p300_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p300_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war on heavy rain.
p300_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p300_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p300_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p300_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p300_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p300_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p300_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p300_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p300_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p301_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p301_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p301_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p301_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p301_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p301_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p301_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p301_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p301_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p301_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p301_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p301_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p301_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p301_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p301_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p301_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p301_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p301_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p301_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p302_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p302_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p302_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p302_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p302_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p302_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he's looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p302_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p302_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p302_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the god to foretell war or heavy rain.
p302_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p302_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p302_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p302_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p302_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p302_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drop increases.
p302_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of a super-imposition of a number of bows.
p302_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green yellow light when mixed form yellow.
p302_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p303_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p303_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p303_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p303_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p303_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p303_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p303_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p303_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p303_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p303_015.txt|The Greeks used it to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p303_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from the earth to their home in the sky.
p303_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p303_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p303_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p303_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p303_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p303_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p303_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p303_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p304_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p304_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p304_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arc, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p304_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p304_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p304_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p304_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p304_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p304_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p304_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p304_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p304_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p304_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p304_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p304_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p304_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p304_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p304_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p304_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p305_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p305_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p305_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p305_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p305_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p305_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p305_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p305_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p305_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p305_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p305_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p305_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p305_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p305_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p305_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.

p306_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p306_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p306_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its paths high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p306_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p306_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p306_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p306_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p306_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p306_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p306_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p306_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p306_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p306_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p306_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p306_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p306_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p306_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p306_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p306_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p307_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p307_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p307_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p307_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p307_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p307_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p307_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p307_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p307_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p307_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p307_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p307_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p307_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p307_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p307_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p307_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p307_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p307_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p307_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p308_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p308_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p308_008.txt|They take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p308_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p308_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p308_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p308_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p308_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p308_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p308_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p308_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p308_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p308_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p308_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p308_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p308_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p308_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition on a number of bows.
p308_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p308_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p310_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes the raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p310_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p310_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and these two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p310_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p310_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p310_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p310_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p310_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without any physical explanation.
p310_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p310_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p310_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which gods passed from earth to the home in the skies.
p310_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p310_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p310_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbow.
p310_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p310_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p310_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p310_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p310_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p311_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p311_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p311_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p311_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p311_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p311_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of a rainbow.
p311_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p311_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p311_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p311_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p311_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p311_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p311_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p311_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p311_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p311_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p311_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p311_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p311_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p312_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p312_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p312_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p312_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p312_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p312_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he's looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p312_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p312_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p312_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p312_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p312_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p312_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p312_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p312_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p312_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbows have been formed.
p312_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increase as the size of the drops increases.
p312_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p312_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p312_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p313_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p313_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p313_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p313_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p313_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p313_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p313_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p313_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p313_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p313_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p313_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p313_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p313_018.txt|Aristotle thought the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p313_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p313_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p313_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the sizes of the drops increases.
p313_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of a super-imposition of a number of bows.
p313_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p313_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p314_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p314_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p314_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p314_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p314_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p314_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p314_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p314_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p314_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p314_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p314_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p314_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p314_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p314_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p314_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p314_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p314_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p314_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p314_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p316_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p316_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p316_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arc, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p316_009.txt|There is , according to a legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p316_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p316_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p316_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p316_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p316_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p316_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p316_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from the earth to their home in the sky.
p316_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p316_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p316_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but the refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p316_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p316_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increase.
p316_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p316_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.

p317_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p317_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p317_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p317_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p317_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p317_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p317_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p317_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p317_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p317_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p317_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p317_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p317_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p317_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p317_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p317_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p317_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p317_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p317_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p318_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p318_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p318_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p318_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p318_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p318_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p318_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p318_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p318_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p318_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p318_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from the earth to their home in the sky.
p318_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p318_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p318_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p318_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p318_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p318_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p318_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p318_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p323_002.txt|Ask her to bring these things with her from the store.
p323_003.txt|Six spoons of fresh snow peas, five thick slabs of blue cheese, and maybe a snack for her brother Bob.

p323_005.txt|She can scoop these things into three red bags, and we will go meet her Wednesday at the train station.
p323_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p323_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p323_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p323_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p323_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p323_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p323_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p323_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p323_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p323_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p323_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p323_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p323_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p323_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p323_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p323_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p323_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p323_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.

p326_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p326_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p326_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p326_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p326_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p326_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p326_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p326_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p326_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p326_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p326_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from the earth to their home in the sky.
p326_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p326_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p326_019.txt|Since then physicists have found it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p326_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p326_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p326_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p326_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p326_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p329_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p329_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p329_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p329_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p329_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p329_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p329_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p329_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p329_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p329_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p329_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p329_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p329_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p329_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p329_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p329_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p329_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p329_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p329_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p330_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p330_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p330_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p330_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p330_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p330_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p330_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p330_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p330_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p330_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p330_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p330_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p330_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p330_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p330_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p330_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p330_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p330_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p330_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p333_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p333_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p333_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arc, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p333_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p333_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p333_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p333_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p333_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p333_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p333_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p333_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p333_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p333_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p333_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not a reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p333_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p333_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p333_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p333_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p333_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p334_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p334_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p334_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p334_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p334_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p334_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p334_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p334_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p334_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p334_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p334_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from the earth to their home in the sky.
p334_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p334_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p334_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p334_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p334_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p334_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p334_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p334_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p335_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p335_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p335_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arc, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p335_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p335_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p335_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p335_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p335_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p335_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p335_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p335_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p335_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p335_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p335_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p335_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p335_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p335_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p335_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p336_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p336_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p336_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p336_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p336_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p336_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p336_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p336_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p336_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p336_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p336_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p336_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p336_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p336_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p336_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p336_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p336_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p336_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed forms yellow.
p336_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.
