p339_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p339_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p339_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p339_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p339_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p339_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p339_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p339_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p339_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p339_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p339_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p339_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p339_018.txt|Aristotle thought the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p339_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbow.
p339_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p339_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p339_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p339_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p339_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p340_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes the raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p340_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p340_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p340_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p340_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p340_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p340_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p340_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p340_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p340_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p340_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p340_017.txt|Others have tried to explain this phenomenon physically.
p340_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p340_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p340_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p340_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p340_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.

p341_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p341_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p341_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p341_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p341_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p341_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p341_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p341_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without any physical explanation.
p341_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p341_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p341_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p341_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p341_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p341_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p341_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p341_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p341_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p341_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p341_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p343_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p343_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.

p345_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p345_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p345_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p345_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p345_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p345_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p345_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p345_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p345_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p345_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p345_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p345_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p345_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p345_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p345_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p345_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p345_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p345_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p345_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p347_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p347_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p347_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p347_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p347_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p347_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p347_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p347_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p347_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p347_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p347_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p347_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p347_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p347_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p347_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p347_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p347_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p347_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p347_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p351_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p351_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p351_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p351_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p351_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p351_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p351_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p351_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p351_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p351_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p351_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p351_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p351_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p351_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p351_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p351_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p351_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p351_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p351_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p360_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p360_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p360_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p360_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p360_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p360_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p360_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p360_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p360_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p360_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p360_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p360_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p360_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p360_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p360_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p360_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p360_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p360_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p360_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p361_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p361_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p361_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p361_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p361_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p361_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p361_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p361_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p361_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p361_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p361_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p361_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p361_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p361_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p361_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p361_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p361_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p361_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p361_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p362_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p362_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p362_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p362_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p362_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p362_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p362_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p362_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p362_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p362_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p362_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p362_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p362_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p362_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p362_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p362_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p362_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p362_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p362_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p363_006.txt|When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow.
p363_007.txt|The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.
p363_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p363_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p363_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p363_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p363_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p363_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p363_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p363_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p363_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p363_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p363_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p363_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbows.
p363_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p363_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p363_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p363_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p363_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.

p364_008.txt|These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon.
p364_009.txt|There is , according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
p364_010.txt|People look, but no one ever finds it.
p364_011.txt|When a man looks for something beyond his reach, his friends say he is looking for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.
p364_012.txt|Throughout the centuries people have explained the rainbow in various ways.
p364_013.txt|Some have accepted it as a miracle without physical explanation.
p364_014.txt|To the Hebrews it was a token that there would be no more universal floods.
p364_015.txt|The Greeks used to imagine that it was a sign from the gods to foretell war or heavy rain.
p364_016.txt|The Norsemen considered the rainbow as a bridge over which the gods passed from earth to their home in the sky.
p364_017.txt|Others have tried to explain the phenomenon physically.
p364_018.txt|Aristotle thought that the rainbow was caused by reflection of the sun's rays by the rain.
p364_019.txt|Since then physicists have found that it is not reflection, but refraction by the raindrops which causes the rainbow.
p364_020.txt|Many complicated ideas about the rainbow have been formed.
p364_021.txt|The difference in the rainbow depends considerably upon the size of the drops, and the width of the colored band increases as the size of the drops increases.
p364_022.txt|The actual primary rainbow observed is said to be the effect of super-imposition of a number of bows.
p364_023.txt|If the red of the second bow falls upon the green of the first, the result is to give a bow with an abnormally wide yellow band, since red and green light when mixed form yellow.
p364_024.txt|This is a very common type of bow, one showing mainly red and yellow, with little or no green or blue.
